Title.evidence: Impact of Transit-Time Flow Measurement on Postoperative Outcomes in Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting: A Retrospective Analysis

Participants.evidence: 910 patients undergoing isolated total arterial coronary artery bypass grafting with internal thoracic arteries (ITAs) at our institution between January 2017 and February 2020

Intervention.evidence: Participants were divided based on the use of TTFM: 430 patients in the TTFM group and 480 in the no TTFM group

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the impact of transit-time flow measurement (TTFM) on early postoperative outcomes in total arterial coronary revascularization

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the occurrence of in-hospital major cardiac adverse events (MACE), including mortality, myocardial infarction, and need for revascularization

Number_Randomised.evidence: 910 patients undergoing isolated total arterial coronary artery bypass grafting with internal thoracic arteries (ITAs) at our institution between January 2017 and February 2020

Number_Analysed.evidence: Participants were divided based on the use of TTFM: 430 patients in the TTFM group and 480 in the no TTFM group

Result_Outcome.evidence: TTFM was protective against MACE occurrence (odds ratio 0.46, 95% CI 0.23â€“0.85, P = 0.016)

Harms.evidence: Six (1.4%) patients in the TTFM group underwent intraoperative graft revision due to unsatisfactory flow values, compared to none in the no TTFM group (P = 0.011)
